question: It is true that an identifier can start with a digit in Python.
It is false that Python keywords can be used as variable names.
It is true that Python is case-sensitive when it comes to identifiers.
It is false that indentation is optional in Python.
It is true that Python requires proper indentation to execute code.
It is false that 'for', 'while', and 'if' are not keywords in Python.
It is true that Python allows the use of special characters like @ and $ in identifiers.
It is false that variable names in Python must always start with an underscore (_).
It is true that comments in Python can be single-line or multi-line.
It is false that Python ignores comments when executing a program.
It is true that an identifier can contain letters, numbers, and underscores (_).
It is false that indentation errors in Python do not cause execution failures.
It is true that Python uses indentation instead of curly braces {} for code blocks.
It is false that 'print' is not a keyword in Python.
It is true that variables in Python can change their data type during execution.
It is false that Python enforces strict static typing for variables.
It is true that 'import' is a keyword used to bring external modules into a Python program.
It is false that variables in Python must be declared with a specific data type.
It is true that identifiers cannot contain spaces in Python.
It is false that Python allows the use of hyphens (-) in identifiers.
It is true that Python keywords have predefined meanings and cannot be used as variable names.
It is false that Python ignores indentation when executing code.
It is true that Python automatically detects the type of data stored in a variable.
It is false that all Python statements must be written on separate lines.
It is true that multi-line comments in Python can be written using triple quotes (''' or "").
